title: Airworthiness Directives; Airbus Canada Limited Partnership (Type Certificate Previously Held by C Series Aircraft Limited Partnership (CSALP); Bombardier, Inc.) Airplanes
summary:
The Federal Aviation Administration has issued a final rule requiring airlines to install updated flight control software on Airbus Canada Model BD‑500‑1A10 and BD‑500‑1A11 airplanes. This replaces a 2022 temporary limitation in the flight manual and directly targets a safety risk identified in service.

What’s changing is straightforward: operators must load new software that fixes problems tied to false cockpit warnings and the chance of the autopilot switching on during the takeoff roll or ground spoilers deploying when they shouldn’t. These issues could increase pilot workload and, in rare cases, reduce safety margins. With the new software in place, the earlier flight manual warning and restrictions can be removed. The rule follows similar action by Canada’s aviation authority and takes effect October 23, 2025.

The beneficiaries are clear. Passengers and crews gain from a wider safety margin during critical phases of flight. Pilots should see fewer nuisance alerts and more predictable behavior from the aircraft’s systems. Airlines may also benefit from fewer spurious messages and less disruption tied to troubleshooting, once the update is in place. A major pilot union publicly supported the proposal earlier this year, signaling front‑line confidence in the fix.

There are trade‑offs. Airlines will face direct costs to comply—up to about $10,425 per airplane in parts and labor, with 133 U.S. airplanes affected—plus any downtime needed to schedule the update alongside other maintenance. While regulators do not expect a significant economic impact on smaller businesses, the expense and planning effort are real, especially for carriers with tight schedules or limited spare aircraft.

Overall, this is a targeted safety upgrade that turns a temporary cockpit limitation into a permanent technical fix. Operators can find the full details and compliance paths in the final rule and associated materials referenced by the agency.
